**_[Anatomical terms of bone](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_bone "Anatomical terms
of bone")_** [[edit on Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q426139
"d:Q426139")]  
  
The **foramen magnum** ([Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): _great
hole_) is a large oval opening ([foramen](/wiki/Foramen "Foramen")) in the
[occipital bone](/wiki/Occipital_bone "Occipital bone") of the
[skull](/wiki/Skull "Skull") in humans and various other
[animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal"). It is one of [the several oval or circular
openings (foramina)](/wiki/List_of_foramina_of_the_human_body "List of
foramina of the human body") in the [base of the skull](/wiki/Base_of_skull
"Base of skull"). The [spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord"), an
extension of the [medulla](/wiki/Medulla_oblongata "Medulla oblongata"),
passes through the foramen magnum as it exits the [cranial
cavity](/wiki/Cranial_cavity "Cranial cavity"). Apart from the transmission of
the medulla oblongata and its membranes, the foramen magnum transmits the
[vertebral arteries](/wiki/Vertebral_artery "Vertebral artery"), the
[anterior](/wiki/Anterior_spinal_artery "Anterior spinal artery") and
[posterior spinal arteries](/wiki/Posterior_spinal_artery "Posterior spinal
artery"), the [tectorial membranes](/wiki/Tectorial_membrane_of_atlanto-
axial_joint "Tectorial membrane of atlanto-axial joint") and [alar
ligaments](/wiki/Alar_ligament "Alar ligament"). It also transmits the spinal
component of the [accessory nerve](/wiki/Accessory_nerve "Accessory nerve")
into the skull.

The **opisthion** is the midpoint on the posterior margin of the foramen
magnum and is a [cephalometric
landmark](/wiki/Cephalometric_analysis#Cephalometric_landmarks "Cephalometric
analysis"). Another landmark is the **basion** located at the midpoint on the
anterior margin of the foramen magnum.

The foramen magnum is a very important feature in bipedal mammals. One of the
attributes of a bipedal animal’s foramen magnum is a forward shift of the
anterior border; this is caused by the shortening of the cranial base. Studies
on the foramen magnum position have shown a connection to the functional
influences of both posture and locomotion. The forward shift of the foramen
magnum is apparent in bipedal hominins, including modern humans,
_Australopithecus africanus_ , and _Paranthropus boisei_. This common feature
of bipedal [hominins](/wiki/Hominini "Hominini") is the driving argument used
by [Michel Brunet](/wiki/Michel_Brunet_\(paleontologist\) "Michel Brunet
\(paleontologist\)") that _[Sahelanthropus
tchadensis](/wiki/Sahelanthropus_tchadensis "Sahelanthropus tchadensis")_ was
also bipedal, and may be the earliest known bipedal ape. The discovery of this
feature has given scientists another form of identifying bipedal mammals. [1]

## Compartments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foramen_magnum&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Compartments")]

The [alar ligament](/wiki/Alar_ligament "Alar ligament") which is attached on
each side to the tubercle of [occipital condyle](/wiki/Occipital_condyle
"Occipital condyle") on each side of Foramen magnum divides it into anterior
smaller compartment and posterior larger compartment;[2]

  * Structures passing through anterior compartment (osseo-ligamentous compartment) are 
    * [Apical ligament](/wiki/Apical_ligament "Apical ligament") and tip of [dens](/wiki/Dens_\(anatomy\) "Dens \(anatomy\)")
    * Upper band of [Cruciate ligament](/wiki/Cruciate_ligament "Cruciate ligament")
    * [Membrana tectoria](/wiki/Membrana_tectoria "Membrana tectoria")
  * Structures passing through posterior compartment (Neuro-vascular compartment) are 
    * Lower end of [Medulla Oblongata](/wiki/Medulla_Oblongata "Medulla Oblongata") with [meninges](/wiki/Meninges "Meninges")
    * Fourth part of [vertebral artery](/wiki/Vertebral_artery "Vertebral artery") surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    * Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    * Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    * Tonsil of [cerebellum](/wiki/Cerebellum "Cerebellum") (occasionally)

## Other
animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Foramen_magnum&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Other animals")]

In humans, the foramen magnum is farther underneath the head than in the other
[great apes](/wiki/Great_apes "Great apes"). Thus, in humans, the neck muscles
(including the [occipitofrontalis muscle](/wiki/Occipitofrontalis_muscle
"Occipitofrontalis muscle")) do not need to be as robust in order to hold the
head upright. Comparisons of the position of the foramen magnum in early
hominid species are useful to determine how comfortable a particular species
was when walking on two limbs ([bipedalism](/wiki/Bipedalism "Bipedalism"))
rather than four ([quadrupedalism](/wiki/Quadrupedalism "Quadrupedalism")).
